content: Hi , It looks like communication http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/patient-definitions.html#Patient.communication can be used to capture a patient's language preferences. The question however is how do we indicate the first language or proficiency or ability in a language ? For example - if we have to represent that a patient has difficulty reading or writing English .

I remember when we designed this part of Patient - we agreed that language proficiency was outside "the 80%", i.e. only interesting to a small part of the implementer community. So, you need extensions to convey proficiency for now.
You could submit a change request for the WG to define a standard extension.
There is a preferred flag on the patient's communication to indicate which language should be used for communicating health information with (even if there are others present)

Thanks for the prompt reply all ! I still think that for a person , first language and preferred language might be different , especially in a multilingual family . But I can understand that it again falls into 20% cases. So what is the best way to represent questions like - Do you have difficulty understanding English? or Do you have any difficulties reading / writing English? I am asking because from the answers above it is not clear if this warrants an extension .

There is a standard extension for using in this use case where the patient is identified as not being able to speak the native language assumed by the system.
http://hl7.org/fhir/extension-patient-interpreterrequired.html
And then the languages lists in the communication provide the detail of which languages are available, and hence which interpreter to get.
we need to add to create a communication resource as an channel for the subscription resource
